title: 106_hr1304
content: The Act titled "Quality Health-Care Coalition Act of 2000" applies antitrust laws to health care professionals negotiating with health plans. Health care professionals negotiating with health plans are entitled to the same treatment under antitrust laws as recognized bargaining units under the National Labor Relations Act. They are protected for good faith actions taken in connection with negotiations. The exemption under subsection (a) from antitrust laws does not subject individuals to criminal sanctions or civil penalties beyond actual damages incurred. It does not grant new rights for collective cessation of service and only applies to health care professionals not covered by the National Labor Relations Act. This exemption has a 3-year sunset provision. The exemption under subsection (a) applies to conduct within a 3-year period from enactment and continues for 1 year after. It does not exempt unlawful agreements limiting health care professionals' services within their scope of practice. It does not affect the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The exemption under subsection (a) of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 does not apply to negotiations between health care professionals and health plans regarding specific federal programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, SCHIP, medical and dental care for uniformed services members, Veterans' medical care, and Federal employees' health benefits program. The Indian Health Care Improvement Act is exempt from negotiations related to abortion services. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of this section and submit a report to Congress with recommendations for extension. Definitions are provided for clarity. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of the section and provide recommendations to Congress for extension. Definitions for "antitrust laws" and "health plan" are clarified. The terms "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" are defined under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The term "group health plan" is also defined under the same Act. A "health care professional" is an individual who provides health care services to patients. The Congress emphasizes that medical decisions should be made by healthcare professionals in consultation with patients. Healthcare professionals provide specialized treatment, assistance, and medications to patients as required by law. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on June 30, 2000.
